question: Question_01_(c)
statement:
Given the matrix

\[A = \begin{bmatrix}
-10 & 0 & 0\\ 
0 & -3.5 & 0 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0.5
\end{bmatrix}\]

Determine the matrix norm of \emph{A} and \emph{cond(A)}.
sols:
For a diagonal matrix, the matrix norm is just the maximum absolute
value of the diagonal entries. The diagonal values on a diagonal matrix
are its eigenvalues.

The matrix norm for matrix
A\[\left| \left| A \right| \right| = max \left\{ \left| \lambda_{i} \right| \right\}\]
where $\lambda_{i}$ are the eigenvalues of matrix A (its diagonal
entries).

Therefore,

$\left| \left| A \right| \right| = max \left\{ \left| -10 \right|, \left| -3.5 \right|, \left| -0.5 \right| \right\}$
$\left| \left| A \right| \right| = max \left\{ 10, 3.5, 0.5 \right\}$
$\left| \left| A \right| \right| =10$

The condition number ($cond\left( A \right)$) measures the relative
stretching ratio of matrix A. The stretching ratio is defined as
$\frac{max \ stretch}{min \ stretch}$ which then equates to
$\left\| A \right\| \left\| A^{-1} \right\|$.

$cond\left( A \right) = \left\| A \right\| \left\| A^{-1} \right\|$

One way to get the inverse of matrix A is to write an augmented matrix
comparing matrix A to the identity matrix I.

$\left[ A | I \right]$

$=
\begin{bmatrix}
10 & 0 & 0\ \ \ \ |& 1 & 0 & 0\\ 
0 & 3.5 & 0\ \ \ \ | & 0 & 1 & 0\\ 
0 & 0 & 0.5\ | & 0 & 0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}$

The next steps are to row reduce until you get the identity matrix on
the left side, and then you will get the inverse of matrix A on the
right. This is simple for matrix A since it is a diagonal matrix. All
you need to do is to divide each row by the entry on its diagonal to
make the entry equal to 1. After you complete this, it should look like
this:

$\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0\ \ \ \ |& \frac{1}{10} & 0 & 0\\ 
0 & 1 & 0\ \ \ \ | & 0 & \frac{2}{7} & 0\\ 
0 & 0 & 1\ \ \ \ | & 0 & 0 & 2
\end{bmatrix}$

Therefore, the inverse of matrix A is:

$A^{-1} = 
\begin{bmatrix}
& \frac{1}{10} & 0 & 0\\ 
& 0 & \frac{2}{7} & 0\\ 
& 0 & 0 & 2
\end{bmatrix}$

We get the matrix norm for $A^{-1}$ just like how we got it for A. Since
$A^{-1}$ is still a diagonal matrix, we still use for method given
above.

$\left\| A^{-1} \right\| = max\{ |\frac{1}{10}|, |\frac{2}{7}|, |2|\}$
$\left\| A^{-1} \right\| = 2$

Now that we have $\| A \|$ and $\| A^{-1} \|$, we can get the condition
number by multiplying them together.

$cond\left( A \right) = \left\| A \right\| \left\| A^{-1} \right\|$
$cond\left( A \right) = 10 * 2$ $cond\left( A \right) = 20$

FINAL ANSWER

$\left| \left| A \right| \right| =10$ $cond\left( A \right) = 20$
